abstract_problem: We are playing a script-based murder mystery game where I play the owner of a freight company with a total market value of W billion. I have been assigned a task: transport goods from N1 factories to N2 customers. We must select specific routes to open from N1*N2 possible options and determine the quantity of goods transported on each route (which does not have to be an integer). When selecting routes, I must communicate with at least N game DMs. Opening each route requires paying a fixed cost, as shown in Table C1. Additionally, transporting one unit of cargo on each route incurs a shipping fee, as shown in Table C2. The quantity of goods produced by each factory is fixed, as shown in Table C3; the quantity transported out of a factory must equal its production volume. The quantity of goods required by each customer is also fixed, as shown in Table C4; the quantity received by each customer must equal their demand. Our objective is to determine the minimum cost to be paid while satisfying all conditions.

files_1.description: The first column of Table C₁ lists factory numbers, and the first row lists customer numbers. The value at each row-column intersection represents the fixed cost for opening the transportation route from the corresponding factory to the corresponding customer.

files_2.description: The first column of Table C₂ lists factory numbers, and the first row lists customer numbers. The value at each row-column intersection represents the unit shipping cost for transporting goods via the route from the corresponding factory to the corresponding customer.

files_3.description: The first column of Table C₃ lists factory numbers, and the second column lists the production volume of each factory—all goods produced must be shipped out in full.

files_4.description: The first column of Table C₄ lists customer numbers, and the second column lists the demand volume of each customer—the quantity of goods received by the customer must exactly meet its demand.
